atAGlanceSummary.title: Overall: Good Health with Room for Improvement

negatives.title: Slightly Elevated Triglycerides
negatives.description: Your triglyceride level of 175 mg/dL is above the optimal range. This is often related to diet, particularly sugar and refined carb intake. The good news is this responds well to lifestyle changes.

negatives.title: Borderline LDL & Blood Pressure
negatives.description: Your LDL cholesterol (118) and blood pressure (128/80) are slightly above optimal. These are early warning signs that can be easily improved with diet and exercise.

positives.title: Excellent Blood Sugar Control
positives.description: Your fasting glucose of 95 mg/dL is perfect! This shows your body is handling sugar efficiently and you're not at risk for diabetes.

positives.title: Good Overall Cholesterol
positives.description: Your total cholesterol of 195 mg/dL is within the healthy range. With some minor adjustments, you can optimize this further.

positives.title: Strong Foundation
positives.description: Most of your health markers are in good shape. You're starting from a position of strength, which means small changes will yield big results.

riskAnalysis.title: Understanding Your Health Profile
riskAnalysis.summary: Your health is generally good, but a few markers suggest dietary and lifestyle tweaks could take you from good to optimal.

riskFactors.title: Elevated Triglycerides
riskFactors.summary: Triglycerides are a type of fat in your blood. Levels above 150 often indicate too much sugar or refined carbohydrates in your diet, or consuming calories close to bedtime.
causes: High sugar intake (sodas, sweets, processed foods)
Excess refined carbohydrates (white bread, pasta, rice)
effects: Increases heart disease risk over time

riskFactors.title: Borderline LDL Cholesterol
riskFactors.summary: LDL (bad cholesterol) at 118 is in the borderline high range. While not critical, lowering it to below 100 would reduce cardiovascular risk.
causes: Dietary saturated fats (red meat, full-fat dairy, fried foods)
effects: Can build up in arterial walls

riskFactors.title: Low-Normal Vitamin D
riskFactors.summary: Your Vitamin D at 28 ng/mL is just below optimal. This vitamin is crucial for bone health, immunity, and mood regulation.

actionPlan.title: Your 30-Day Optimization Plan
actionPlan.summary: These are simple, sustainable changes that will bring your numbers into optimal range. No extreme measures neededâ€”just smart, consistent choices.

focusAreas.title: Nutrition
focusAreas.goal: Reduce triglycerides and optimize cholesterol through smart eating.
rules: Cut back on added sugars (aim for <25g per day)
Reduce refined carbsâ€”choose whole grains instead
Add more omega-3 rich foods (salmon, walnuts, flaxseed)
Eat your largest meal at lunch, lighter dinner before 7 PM

focusAreas.title: Physical Activity
focusAreas.goal: Boost metabolism and improve cardiovascular health.
rules: 30 minutes of moderate cardio, 5 days a week (brisk walking, cycling, swimming)
Add 2 days of strength training per week
Take movement breaks every hour if you have a desk job

focusAreas.title: Supplementation
focusAreas.goal: Address vitamin D deficiency and support heart health.
rules: Vitamin D3: 2,000 IU daily with meals
Consider a quality multivitamin for overall support

focusAreas.title: Lifestyle Habits
focusAreas.goal: Build healthy routines that support metabolic health.
rules: Get 7-8 hours of quality sleep per night
Manage stress through meditation, yoga, or deep breathing
Stay hydrated (8 glasses of water daily)
Get 15-20 minutes of sun exposure daily (for vitamin D)

supplementPrescription.title: Recommended Supplements
supplementPrescription.summary: These supplements will help address your specific needs and support your optimization goals.

prescriptions.title: Vitamin D3 (2,000 IU)
prescriptions.dosage: 2,000 IU daily with a meal containing fat
prescriptions.instructions: Take in the morning with breakfast for optimal absorption.

prescriptions.title: Omega-3 Fish Oil
prescriptions.instructions: Take with your largest meal to reduce fishy aftertaste.

prescriptions.title: Psyllium Husk Fiber
prescriptions.instructions: Take before meals to help reduce cholesterol absorption.

motivationalSummary.title: Your Path Forward
motivationalSummary.primaryMessage: You're in a great position! Your health is fundamentally sound, and with a few targeted adjustments, you can move from 'good' to 'optimal.' These aren't drastic changesâ€”they're smart, sustainable improvements.
motivationalSummary.proofOfSuccess: The fact that most of your markers are already in healthy ranges shows your body responds well. The slightly elevated triglycerides and LDL are your body's way of saying 'I need a bit more support'â€”and you can provide that easily.
motivationalSummary.nextSteps: Focus on the nutrition and exercise changes for the next 30 days. You'll likely see your triglycerides drop by 20-30% and feel more energetic. This is about optimization, not desperationâ€”enjoy the journey!
motivationalSummary.closingThought: Small, consistent changes compound into remarkable results. You've got this! ðŸ’ª
